item.title: INTERCHANGE
item.description:
INTERCHANGE

Jeffrey Gibson: They Teach Love From the Collections of Jordan D. Schnitzer and His Family Foundation presents a sweeping survey of over thirty-five objects spanning fifteen years. The exhibition includes prints, photography, painting, sculpture, installation, and video. The inclusion of contemporary adornment in fashion is influenced by intertribal powwows as well as the dance clubs where Gibson found safe spaces as a teenager. The exhibition’s centerpiece is an expansive and immersive work titled To Name An Other—fifty-one printed elk hide drums and fifty wearable garments, which was originally commissioned as a performance by the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery in 2019. Born in Colorado in 1972, Jeffrey Gibson is of Cherokee heritage and a member of the Mississippi Band of Choctaw. His vibrant work, which is represented in more than twenty permanent collections across the United States, is a call for Indigenous empowerment as well as queer visibility. Gibson has a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and received a Master of Fine Arts from the Royal College of Art, London. Gibson is representing the United States at the Venice Biennale 2024—the first indigenous artist to have a solo exhibition in the American Pavilion. This traveling exhibition is organized by the Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art, Washington State University and is curated by Ryan Hardesty, Executive Director. 


Organized by the Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art. Support for this exhibition and related education and outreach programs has been made possible by a grant from the Jordan Schnitzer Family Foundation. 

From Thursday, October 17, 2024 7:00 PM to 7:30 PM EDT at Zuckerman Museum of Art.
item.author: zma@kennesaw.edu (Zuckerman Museum of Art)

item.title: Discover Recovery
item.description:
Discover Recovery

This is a weekly community and skill building workshop designed to provide support to students in early recovery by enhancing the ability to navigate their collegiate career while also emerging into recovery, build their recovery capital, and learn to develop interpersonal skills. 

Discover Recovery is for any student seeking recovery or is in their first 6 months of recovery. We support students who are in or seeking recovery from substance use disorders, eating disorders, and other process addictions. For more information or directions to the Center for Young Adult Addiction and Recovery, email recovery@kennesaw.edu

From Monday, October 21, 2024 3:30 PM to 4:30 PM EDT at Kennesaw Campus CYAAR Location - University Village 6000 Building - UV 6138.

item.title: Getting Started with Microsoft Copilot
item.description:
Getting Started with Microsoft Copilot

Join us for an engaging workshop delving into the exciting world of Microsoft Copilot, a powerful AI (artificial intelligence) tool that can generate text, images, and summaries. Learn best practices for using Copilot securely to protect your data as you ask Copilot to answer questions, generate creative content, and even proofread your writing. Whether you’re looking to write a compelling story, create a unique image, or simply make your day-to-day tasks easier, this workshop will help you master AI at KSU!

 

To register for this course, follow the steps below:

1. Click here to navigate to this course in OwlTrain.
2. Scroll down to browse available dates/times for this course.
3. When you find the date/time that you would like to attend, click the Register button on the right side of the page.
4. You have successfully registered for this course! You will receive a reminder email 48 hours before the course starts.
5. To join the course when it starts, click the View Live Course button in either your email or on the OwlTrain course page.

From Tuesday, October 22, 2024 10:00 AM to 11:00 AM EDT at Online.

item.title: RIO #3: Recognition, Insight, Openness
item.description:
RIO #3: Recognition, Insight, Openness
Feeling Overwhelmed and looking to get "Unstuck"? 
 
Recognition, Insight, Openness (RIO) is a 3-week, curriculum-driven workshop designed to help students gain insight into their concerns, develop a clear sense of what they would like to change in their lives, and identify tools and concrete strategies to reduce feelings of stress and improve emotional functioning.
 
RIO teaches students techniques for recognizing and moving past situations that cause stress, frustration, and anxiety. 
  • Manage and reduce anxiety.
  • Adapt to new challenges.
  • Understand your thoughts and feelings, WITHOUT judgment or shame.
  • Move beyond feeling “stuck”.
  • Take the initiative to step out of your comfort zone.
RIO #3 will meet in-person for 3 consecutive weeks: Wednesday, Oct. 23, Oct. 30, and Nov. 6 at 11:00am.
MARIETTA CAMPUS, JoeMack Wilson Student Center, room A215
 

From Wednesday, October 23, 2024 11:00 AM to 12:00 PM EDT at Marietta Campus, JoeMack Wilson Std Ctr, A215.

item.description:
Cooking Basics: Rice & Veggies

Want some meal options that don’t include a paper bag and extra napkins? Why not learn some cooking tips for those busy days or when the money is tight? A KSU dietitian will show you how to cook some basic meals whether you have a full kitchen, a common kitchen in the dorm, or just a microwave in the lobby. And, as always, there will be snacks! 

We will be making some quick, budget-friendly options. Noodles with sauce and rice with stir fry. Roasted, stir fried, steamed- all veggies are good veggies!. Yum!

Space is limited and registration is required

From Wednesday, October 23, 2024 1:00 PM to 2:00 PM EDT at SRAC 1220.

item.title: Virtual Talk with Cherokee science fiction author Blake Hausman
item.description:
Virtual Talk with Cherokee science fiction author Blake Hausman

Blake Hausman, Cherokee science fiction author of Riding the Trail of Tears, will join KSU for a virtual visit with Dr. Miriam Brown Spiers (Assoc Prof of English and Director of American Studies) and Dr. Rochelle Harris Cox (Sr Lecturer of English) on Wednesday, October 23 at 3pm in ALC 4201.

Blake Hausman is an enrolled citizen of the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma. He lives with his family in Portland, OR, where he teaches English, Reading, Writing, and Native American Studies at Portland Community College. He also teaches Ethnic Studies with Oregon State University's Ecampus. Blake's first novel, Riding the Trail of Tears (2011), is a surrealistic revisitation of the Cherokee Removal. He is nearing completion of a second novel, a new work of Indigenous Futurism. (credit)

From Wednesday, October 23, 2024 3:00 PM to 5:00 PM EDT at Academic Learning Center, Room 4201, Kennesaw Campus.

item.title: Self-Injury Recovery & Awareness (SIRA)
item.description:
Self-Injury Recovery & Awareness (SIRA)

The Center for Young Adult Addiction and Recovery now hosts an on-campus Self-Injury Recovery & Awareness (SIRA - formerly known as Self-Injury Recovery Anonymous) meeting. This Meeting of SIRA is for people in recovery or seeking recovery. This group is not open to observation or academic credit.

To provide a safe space for individuals who engage in physical self-injury to come together to share experiences, strength, and hope without judgment or criticism. Together, we deepen our understanding of our behaviors and triggers and work within the framework of our program to help ourselves and each other on our path to freedom. The only requirement for membership is a desire to stop injuring oneself physically.

From Wednesday, October 23, 2024 7:00 PM to 8:00 PM EDT at Kennesaw Campus CYAAR Location - University Village 6000 Building - UV 6138.

item.title: Ecology, Evolution, Behavior, & Organismal Biology (EEBOB) seminar series
item.description:
Ecology, Evolution, Behavior, & Organismal Biology (EEBOB) seminar series

Speaker: Michael Ogle, Curator of Herpetology at Zoo Knoxville
Title: “TBA”
Abstract: TBA

 

The Ecology, Evolution, Behavior, & Organismal Biology (EEBOB) seminar series focuses on biological topics at whole-organism and higher scales of organization. Guest speakers come from universities, governmental agencies, NGOs, zoos, museums, and other institutions.

 

This seminar series consists of a pre-recorded seminar, which will be posted to a playlist at the beginning of each week, and a live, virtual Q&A session with the speaker. All are welcome to attend! For access to the live Q&A session, interested attendees can email Dr. Todd Pierson to be granted access. The live Q&A session will be held each Thursday @ 9:30 AM.

item.title: Managing Anxiety & Depression
item.description:
Managing Anxiety & Depression

The Managing Anxiety and Depression virtual workshop will be an educational experience with the opportunity to interact with counselor and group members going through similar struggles. Not a therapy group but designed to begin providing you with knowledge in the healing process, awareness about your mood and to begin practicing these skills on your own. We aim to help you understand:

  • Causes and experiences of anxiety and depression
  • Connection between stress and anxiety/depression
  • New approaches to managing anxiety and depression
  • How the mind and body respond to mental distress
The workshop will be hosted virtually on Microsoft Teams. Students who RSVP thru OwlLife will receive a meeting invitation on the day of the workshop. 

From Thursday, October 24, 2024 1:30 PM to 2:30 PM EDT at Online.

item.title: Wise Choices Workshop
item.description:
Wise Choices Workshop

Designed to educate students in making informed choices about drugs and alcohol, this course is taught on referral from multiple sources; including Student Conduct & Academic Integrity, Department of Fraternity & Sorority Life, Housing & Residence Life, and Department of Athletics. This three-hour workshop is taught by the Center for Young Adult Addiction and Recovery staff specializing in the field of addiction prevention and education. 


Students who participate in the Wise Choices Workshop will be charged an administrative fee for this class. Your Owl Express account will be assessed the amount of $85.00 after completion of the workshop. This fee must be paid within 30 days to avoid a Bursar's registration hold on your account. You may pay this fee on-line through Owl Express (web-check or credit card) or in person at the Bursar's Office (cash, check or money order). Please wait until you have received an email notification that the charge has been posted before you attempt to pay.

From Friday, October 25, 2024 12:00 PM to 3:00 PM EDT at Marietta Campus - JM Wilson Student Center - A216.

item.description:
Start SMART. Stay SMART. Workshop Series - Study Skills/Anxiety

This workshop will help you learn different strategies for studying and preparing for your courses. Environmental Properties, Effective Note Taking, Collaboration, Reading Comprehension Strategies will all be discussed and effective examples given.

Taking exams can be a stressful experience. Many of us experience increased anxiety in the run up to an exam, during an exam time, as well after the exam is finished. This workshop will discuss types of test anxiety and provide tools for combatting it before, during, and after an exam.

item.title: BodyPositiveKSU Book Club (BI)
item.description:
BodyPositiveKSU Book Club (BI)

College can present additional challenges for people experiencing eating and body image issues. Join a KSU dietitian, therapist, and peer counselor for a biweekly book club about body image topics. We will discuss sections of the book and build community while creating a body positive campus. 

 

We will read two books this semester; the discussion schedule is below. Please email Danielle Southern at dsouth13@kennesaw.edu if you have any questions or would like to rent a copy of the book

 

Embody by Connie Sobczak

9/16: Intro, Competency 1-2 
9/30: Competency 3-5

 

Reclaiming Body Trust by Hilary Kinavey and Dana Sturtevant

10/14: Intro, Part 1 
10/28: Part 2 
11/11: Part 3

From Monday, October 28, 2024 3:30 PM to 4:30 PM EDT at Student Recreation and Activities Center Suite 1220.

item.title: You Matter Bonfire
item.description:
You Matter Bonfire

Are you feeling weighed down by the past? Stressed about the present? Or, is it time to let go of those negative thoughts and emotions? We invite you to our YOU MATTER Bonfire - a warm, vibrant experience designed to help you shed mental baggage that's holding you back or hindering your progress. 

Write down the things you want to leave behind: fears, doubt, insecurities, stress, trauma, negative energy, etc. Then, join us by the bonfire and watch as your words are transformed into warmth and light, symbolizing a fresh start. We will also be roasting s'mores and enjoying community around the campfire. 

Come warm up by the fire, reflect & release, and enjoy a toasted s'more!

From Tuesday, October 29, 2024 6:30 PM to 8:00 PM EDT at Campus Green.

item.title: RIO #4: Recognition, Insight, Openness
item.description:
RIO #4: Recognition, Insight, Openness
Feeling Overwhelmed and looking to get "Unstuck"? 
 
Recognition, Insight, Openness (RIO) is a 3-week, curriculum-driven workshop designed to help students gain insight into their concerns, develop a clear sense of what they would like to change in their lives, and identify tools and concrete strategies to reduce feelings of stress and improve emotional functioning.
 
RIO teaches students techniques for recognizing and moving past situations that cause stress, frustration, and anxiety. 
  • Manage and reduce anxiety.
  • Adapt to new challenges.
  • Understand your thoughts and feelings, WITHOUT judgment or shame.
  • Move beyond feeling “stuck”.
  • Take the initiative to step out of your comfort zone.
RIO #4 will meet in-person for 3 consecutive weeks: Wednesday, Oct. 30, Nov. 6, and Nov. 3 at 2:00pm.
Kennesaw Campus, Bagwell Education Bldg, room BEB 129
 

From Wednesday, October 30, 2024 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM EDT at Kennesaw Campus, Bagwell Education, BEB 129.
item.author: counseling@kennesaw.edu (Counseling and Psychological Services)

item.title: Mental Health First Aid (MHFA) Training
item.description:
Mental Health First Aid (MHFA) Training

Mental Health First Aid (MHFA): Pre-work plus instructor-led, in-person, full day. MHFA is a skills-based training course that teaches people how to identify, understand, and respond to signs of mental illness and substance use disorder. People trained in MHFA learn to identify the risk factors and warning signs of mental health problems, strategies to help someone who is developing a mental health problem or is in crisis, and how to reach out and offer resources on where to turn for help. 

The MHFA course consists of 2-hours of self-paced content followed by 6.5 hours of instructor-led training. The self-paced content must be completed before the in-person-led training day. We ask that you block off your calendar for the day with the intent of wrapping up by 4:30 pm. We will break for an hour at lunch, on your own. 

REGISTER by completing the form, Fall 2024 Mental Health Training Registration. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact Chelsea Williams at cwill733@kennesaw.edu. 

From Wednesday, October 30, 2024 9:00 AM to 4:30 PM EDT at Academic Learning Center.

item.title: Self-Injury Recovery & Awareness (SIRA)
item.description:
Self-Injury Recovery & Awareness (SIRA)

The Center for Young Adult Addiction and Recovery now hosts an on-campus Self-Injury Recovery & Awareness (SIRA - formerly known as Self-Injury Recovery Anonymous) meeting. This Meeting of SIRA is for people in recovery or seeking recovery. This group is not open to observation or academic credit.

To provide a safe space for individuals who engage in physical self-injury to come together to share experiences, strength, and hope without judgment or criticism. Together, we deepen our understanding of our behaviors and triggers and work within the framework of our program to help ourselves and each other on our path to freedom. The only requirement for membership is a desire to stop injuring oneself physically.

From Wednesday, October 30, 2024 7:00 PM to 8:00 PM EDT at Kennesaw Campus CYAAR Location - University Village 6000 Building - UV 6138.

Title: “TBA”
Abstract: TBA

 

The Ecology, Evolution, Behavior, & Organismal Biology (EEBOB) seminar series focuses on biological topics at whole-organism and higher scales of organization. Guest speakers come from universities, governmental agencies, NGOs, zoos, museums, and other institutions.

 

This seminar series consists of a pre-recorded seminar, which will be posted to a playlist at the beginning of each week, and a live, virtual Q&A session with the speaker. All are welcome to attend! item.title: Hooty-Boo! Halloween Karaoke
item.description:
Hooty-Boo! Halloween Karaoke

The Center for Young Adult Addiction and Recovery will be hosting a karaoke contest this Halloween! Come perform or cheer on your friends! Don't want to sing, but have an awesome Halloween costume? item.title: Mental Health First Aid (MHFA) Training
item.description:
Mental Health First Aid (MHFA) Training

Mental Health First Aid (MHFA): Pre-work plus instructor-led, in-person, full day. MHFA is a skills-based training course that teaches people how to identify, understand, and respond to signs of mental illness and substance use disorder. People trained in MHFA learn to identify the risk factors and warning signs of mental health problems, strategies to help someone who is developing a mental health problem or is in crisis, and how to reach out and offer resources on where to turn for help. 

The MHFA course consists of 2-hours of self-paced content followed by 6.5 hours of instructor-led training. The self-paced content must be completed before the in-person-led training day. We ask that you block off your calendar for the day with the intent of wrapping up by 4:30 pm. We will break for an hour at lunch, on your own. 

REGISTER by completing the form, Fall 2024 Mental Health Training Registration. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact Chelsea Williams at cwill733@kennesaw.edu. 

From Monday, November 4, 2024 9:00 AM to 4:30 PM EST at Academic Learning Center.

item.title: QPR Training
item.description:
QPR Training
QPR (Question, Persuade, Refer) are three simple steps anyone can learn to help save a life from suicide. People trained in QPR learn how to recognize the warning signs of a suicide crisis and how to question, persuade, and refer someone to help. 


The in-person training will be held on the Kennesaw campus. REGISTER by completing the form, Fall 2024 Mental Health Training Registration. Please register no later than one week before the training date. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact Chelsea Williams at cwill733@kennesaw.edu.

item.title: Self-Injury Recovery & Awareness (SIRA)
item.description:
Self-Injury Recovery & Awareness (SIRA)

The Center for Young Adult Addiction and Recovery now hosts an on-campus Self-Injury Recovery & Awareness (SIRA - formerly known as Self-Injury Recovery Anonymous) meeting. This Meeting of SIRA is for people in recovery or seeking recovery. This group is not open to observation or academic credit.

To provide a safe space for individuals who engage in physical self-injury to come together to share experiences, strength, and hope without judgment or criticism. Together, we deepen our understanding of our behaviors and triggers and work within the framework of our program to help ourselves and each other on our path to freedom. The only requirement for membership is a desire to stop injuring oneself physically.

From Wednesday, November 6, 2024 7:00 PM to 8:00 PM EST at Kennesaw Campus CYAAR Location - University Village 6000 Building - UV 6138.

item.title: Women's Climb Night
item.description:
Women's Climb Night

"After feeling intimidated and discouraged while trying rock climbing for the first time, I realized that many women have also had similar experiences. Recognizing that women are under-represented in the climbing community, a group of staff members decided to host an event specifically for women in the Climbing Gym. Since 2019, we have been able to host Women's Climb Night and successfully introduce women to the sport in a supportive and welcoming environment." - Ransley Cummings, Lead Climbing Instructor 

Scheduled monthly, Women's Climb Night offers a supportive environment for female climbers, no matter their skill level.  Shoes, chalk, and harness rentals are complimentary during the event.  We will have extra female staff to help belay and provide climbing instruction/assistance.  The climbing gym will only be available for women during Women's Climb Night. 

From Wednesday, November 6, 2024 5:00 PM to 8:00 PM EST at KSU Climbing Gym, Student Recreation and Activities Center.

item.title: RIO #5: Recognition, Insight, Openness
item.description:
RIO #5: Recognition, Insight, Openness
Feeling Overwhelmed and looking to get "Unstuck"? 
 
Recognition, Insight, Openness (RIO) is a 3-week, curriculum-driven workshop designed to help students gain insight into their concerns, develop a clear sense of what they would like to change in their lives, and identify tools and concrete strategies to reduce feelings of stress and improve emotional functioning.
 
RIO teaches students techniques for recognizing and moving past situations that cause stress, frustration, and anxiety. 
  • Manage and reduce anxiety.
  • Adapt to new challenges.
  • Understand your thoughts and feelings, WITHOUT judgment or shame.
  • Move beyond feeling “stuck”.
  • Take the initiative to step out of your comfort zone.
RIO #5 will meet in-person for 3 consecutive weeks: Thursday, Nov. 7, Nov. 14, and Nov. 21 at 2:00pm.
Kennesaw Campus, Kennesaw Hall, room KH 1203
 
 

From Thursday, November 7, 2024 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM EST at Kennesaw Campus, Kennesaw Hall, KH 1203.

item.description:
Managing Anxiety & Depression

The Managing Anxiety and Depression virtual workshop will be an educational experience with the opportunity to interact with counselor and group members going through similar struggles. Not a therapy group but designed to begin providing you with knowledge in the healing process, awareness about your mood and to begin practicing these skills on your own. We aim to help you understand:

  • Causes and experiences of anxiety and depression
  • Connection between stress and anxiety/depression
  • New approaches to managing anxiety and depression

item.title: Windgate Artist-in-Residence Lecture: Matthew Kirk
item.description:
Windgate Artist-in-Residence Lecture: Matthew Kirk

Matthew Kirk (b. 1978, Ganado, AZ) is an enrolled member of the Navajo Nation and currently lives and works in Brooklyn, New York. A self-taught artist, Kirk has worked for over twelve years in New York City as a professional art handler— a trade that has often influenced his artistic practice in terms of utilizing readily available materials to make his art. His gestural paintings and abstract assemblages are steeped in symbolism and iconography that relate to the visual language of the Navajo, while his use of the grid as compositional armature takes structural inspiration from traditional Navajo weavings and rugs, as well as topographical maps and urban landscapes. Kirk states, “Just as family, work, current events, and city life are reflected in the work, my Indian heritage plays an important, but nuanced role.” 

From Thursday, November 7, 2024 5:00 PM to 6:00 PM EST at Zuckerman Museum of Art.

item.description:

Learn how to import or connect to external data, and then shape that data (i.e., remove a column, change a data type, or merge tables) in ways that meet your needs. item.title: Naloxone Training
item.description:
Naloxone Training

The Center for Young Adult Addiction and Recovery will host training sessions throughout each semester to teach students how to administer Naloxone, a medication that reverses the effects of an opioid overdose.

At the end of this training the participants will be able to:

  1. Identify potential warning signs of an overdose
  2. Operate and administer Naloxone in the event of an overdose
  3. Identify how Naloxone works
  4. Understand the Georgia Medical Amnesty Law
  5. Practice with Naloxone test kits

Each person who attends & completes training is provided a free Naloxone kit. RSVP is required for training.

From Friday, November 8, 2024 2:00 PM to 3:00 PM EST at Kennesaw Campus CYAAR Location - University Village 6000 Building - UV 6137.

item.title: ArtsKSU Presents: Arianna String Quartet
item.description:
ArtsKSU Presents: Arianna String Quartet
ArtsKSU Series. Hailed for their outstanding musicianship, the Arianna String Quartet has established itself as one of America's finest chamber ensembles. Their performances have been praised for “tonal warmth, fastidious balance and expressive vitality” (Chicago Tribune) and “emotional commitment and fluent virtuosity,” (Pretoria News, South Africa). Formed in 1992, the ASQ garnered national attention by winning the Grand Prize in the Fischoff Chamber Music Competition, First Prize in both the Coleman and Carmel Chamber Music Competitions, and were Laureates in the Bordeaux International String Quartet Competition.

item.title: Mental Health First Aid (MHFA) Training
item.description:
Mental Health First Aid (MHFA) Training

Mental Health First Aid (MHFA): Pre-work plus instructor-led, in-person, full day. MHFA is a skills-based training course that teaches people how to identify, understand, and respond to signs of mental illness and substance use disorder. People trained in MHFA learn to identify the risk factors and warning signs of mental health problems, strategies to help someone who is developing a mental health problem or is in crisis, and how to reach out and offer resources on where to turn for help. 

The MHFA course consists of 2-hours of self-paced content followed by 6.5 hours of instructor-led training. The self-paced content must be completed before the in-person-led training day. We ask that you block off your calendar for the day with the intent of wrapping up by 4:30 pm. We will break for an hour at lunch, on your own. 

REGISTER by completing the form, Fall 2024 Mental Health Training Registration. If you have any questions or concerns, please contact Chelsea Williams at cwill733@kennesaw.edu. 

From Monday, November 11, 2024 9:00 AM to 4:30 PM EST at Academic Learning Center.

To provide a safe space for individuals who engage in physical self-injury to come together to share experiences, strength, and hope without judgment or criticism. Together, we deepen our understanding of our behaviors and triggers and work within the framework of our program to help ourselves and each other on our path to freedom. item.title: Ecology, Evolution, Behavior, & Organismal Biology (EEBOB) seminar series
item.description:
Ecology, Evolution, Behavior, & Organismal Biology (EEBOB) seminar series

Speaker: Dr. Ana María Bedoya, Curator at the New York Botanical Garden
Title: “TBA”
Abstract: TBA

 

The Ecology, Evolution, Behavior, & Organismal Biology (EEBOB) seminar series focuses on biological topics at whole-organism and higher scales of organization. Guest speakers come from universities, governmental agencies, NGOs, zoos, museums, and other institutions.

 

This seminar series consists of a pre-recorded seminar, which will be posted to a playlist at the beginning of each week, and a live, virtual Q&A session with the speaker. All are welcome to attend! For access to the live Q&A session, interested attendees can email Dr. Todd Pierson to be granted access. The live Q&A session will be held each Thursday @ 9:30 AM.

From Thursday, November 14, 2024 9:30 AM to 10:30 AM EST at Online.

item.title: Dining in the Nest - Marietta Campus
item.description:
Dining in the Nest - Marietta Campus
Have you wanted to make new friends but feel anxious or have a hard time finding your community? Have you been stressed out about going to the Commons or Stingers?  Then this is the event for you! We invite you to join the CPS Peer Counselors for lunch! No Meal Plan necessary. Space is LIMITED so please RSVP.
 
For the Marietta campus events, students will meet the Peer Counselors in front of Stingers between 11:45am-12:00pm.  
 
There will be a 5-minute grace period for students to arrive for this event at the meeting locations. Please arrive during this time, as the event will begin promptly. Students who arrive after will not be able to attend.
 
If you cannot attend the event after submitting your RSVP, please cancel your reservation to allow other students to participate.
Maximum 2 sign ups per student.  
 
We look forward to dining with you!

From Friday, November 15, 2024 12:00 PM to 1:00 PM EST at Marietta Campus, Stingers (meet out front at 11:45am).

item.title: Visiting Artist Talk: Catherine Blackburn
item.description:
Visiting Artist Talk: Catherine Blackburn

Inspired by her late Setsuné’s (grandmother) incredible garment making, hide-tanning and adornment, Catherine Blackburn’s work grounds itself in the Indigenous feminine. Join us for an artist talk in which she reflects on her wearable art practice and its intersection between Indigenous dress, collaboration, and community.   
  
Catherine Blackburn was born in Patuanak Saskatchewan and is a member of the English River First Nation (Denesųłiné). She is a multidisciplinary artist and jeweler, whose common themes address Canada's colonial past that are often prompted by personal narratives. Her work grounds itself in the Indigenous feminine and is bound by the ancestral love that stitching suggests. Through stitchwork, she explores Indigenous sovereignty, decolonization, and representation. Her work has been included in renowned national and international exhibitions including Radical Stitch, Àbadakone, Santa Fe Haute Couture Fashion Show, and Toronto Indigenous Fashion Week. She has received numerous awards including the Sobey Art Award longlist (2019/2023), a Forge Residency Fellowship (2022), and an Eiteljorg Fellowship (2021).  

From Friday, November 15, 2024 1:30 PM to 2:30 PM EST at Zuckerman Museum of Art.
item.author: zma@kennesaw.edu (Zuckerman Museum of Art)

item.title: Catherine Blackburn
item.description:
Catherine Blackburn
Inspired by her late Setsuné’s (grandmother) incredible garment- making, hide-tanning, and adornment, artist Catherine Blackburn’s work grounds itself in the Indigenous feminine. Blackburn
will present an artist talk on Friday, November 15 in which she reflects on her wearable art practice and its intersection between Indigenous dress, collaboration, and community. On Saturday, November 16, join Catherine for an Applied Beading Workshop inspired by Aboriginal Classics, a series of works exploring themes of identity, language, and story. Participants will learn applied beading basics on an unconventional medium that utilizes a teabag as the vessel and story-holder.

item.title: Year of Canada: The Artistic Practice of Wearable Art: Indigenous Dress, Collaboration, and Community
item.description:
Year of Canada: The Artistic Practice of Wearable Art: Indigenous Dress, Collaboration, and Community

Inspired by her late Setsuné's (grandmother’s) incredible garment-making, hide-tanning and adornment, Canadian artist Catherine Blackburn's work grounds itself in the Indigenous feminine. Join us for an artist talk in which she reflects on her wearable art practice and its intersection between Indigenous dress, collaboration, and community.

The talk will be accompanied by an Indigenous drumming session and a poster printing event both related to the exhibition by Native American artist Jeffrey Gibson which is on view in the museum. 

Sponsored by Zuckerman Museum of Art and Global Education. This event is part of KSU's International Education Week programming. This event is part of KSU's focus in 2024-25 on Canada's history, culture, geography, people, and practices. Unique "Year of Canada" merch will be available! Check out all of our events listed in OwlLife and online.

From Friday, November 15, 2024 1:30 PM to 4:30 PM EST at Zuckerman Museum of Art (Kennesaw Campus).

item.title: Wise Choices Workshop
item.description:
Wise Choices Workshop

Designed to educate students in making informed choices about drugs and alcohol, this course is taught on referral from multiple sources; including Student Conduct & Academic Integrity, Department of Fraternity & Sorority Life, Housing & Residence Life, and Department of Athletics. This three-hour workshop is taught by the Center for Young Adult Addiction and Recovery staff specializing in the field of addiction prevention and education. 


Students who participate in the Wise Choices Workshop will be charged an administrative fee for this class. Your Owl Express account will be assessed the amount of $85.00 after completion of the workshop. This fee must be paid within 30 days to avoid a Bursar's registration hold on your account. You may pay this fee on-line through Owl Express (web-check or credit card) or in person at the Bursar's Office (cash, check or money order). Please wait until you have received an email notification that the charge has been posted before you attempt to pay.

From Saturday, November 16, 2024 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM EST at Kennesaw Campus CYAAR Location - University Village 6000 Building - UV 6137.

The College of Computing and Software Engineering (CCSE) Computing Showcase (C-Day) is a biannual event that takes place at the end of fall and spring semesters where participating students showcase some of the richest activity at CCSE. item.title: Getting Started with Microsoft Copilot
item.description:
Getting Started with Microsoft Copilot

Join us for an engaging workshop delving into the exciting world of Microsoft Copilot, a powerful AI (artificial intelligence) tool that can generate text, images, and summaries. Learn best practices for using Copilot securely to protect your data as you ask Copilot to answer questions, generate creative content, and even proofread your writing. Whether you’re looking to write a compelling story, create a unique image, or simply make your day-to-day tasks easier, this workshop will help you master AI at KSU!

 

To register for this course, follow the steps below:

1. Click here to navigate to this course in OwlTrain.
2. Scroll down to browse available dates/times for this course.
3. When you find the date/time that you would like to attend, click the Register button on the right side of the page.
4. You have successfully registered for this course! You will receive a reminder email 48 hours before the course starts.
5. To join the course when it starts, click the View Live Course button in either your email or on the OwlTrain course page.

From Wednesday, November 20, 2024 10:00 AM to 11:00 AM EST at Online.
item.author: studenthelpdesk@kennesaw.edu (UITS Technology Outreach)

item.title: Managing Anxiety & Depression
item.description:
Managing Anxiety & Depression

The Managing Anxiety and Depression virtual workshop will be an educational experience with the opportunity to interact with counselor and group members going through similar struggles. Not a therapy group but designed to begin providing you with knowledge in the healing process, awareness about your mood and to begin practicing these skills on your own. We aim to help you understand:

  • Causes and experiences of anxiety and depression
  • Connection between stress and anxiety/depression
  • New approaches to managing anxiety and depression
  • How the mind and body respond to mental distress
The workshop will be hosted virtually on Microsoft Teams. Students who RSVP thru OwlLife will receive a meeting invitation on the day of the workshop. 

From Wednesday, November 20, 2024 10:00 AM to 11:00 AM EST at Online.
item.author: counseling@kennesaw.edu (Counseling and Psychological Services)

item.title: Self-Injury Recovery & Awareness (SIRA)
item.description:
Self-Injury Recovery & Awareness (SIRA)

The Center for Young Adult Addiction and Recovery now hosts an on-campus Self-Injury Recovery & Awareness (SIRA - formerly known as Self-Injury Recovery Anonymous) meeting. This Meeting of SIRA is for people in recovery or seeking recovery. This group is not open to observation or academic credit.

To provide a safe space for individuals who engage in physical self-injury to come together to share experiences, strength, and hope without judgment or criticism. Together, we deepen our understanding of our behaviors and triggers and work within the framework of our program to help ourselves and each other on our path to freedom. The only requirement for membership is a desire to stop injuring oneself physically.

From Wednesday, November 20, 2024 7:00 PM to 8:00 PM EST at Kennesaw Campus CYAAR Location - University Village 6000 Building - UV 6138.
item.location: Kennesaw Campus CYAAR Location - University Village 6000 Building - UV 6138

item.title: Monthly Interview Panel
item.description:
Monthly Interview Panel

Join us for the Monthly Interview Panel at Kennesaw State University, where students have the unique opportunity to engage with a panel of experienced mental health professionals. This interactive event is designed to meet the needs and expectations of student interview projects assigned by professors. Bring your questions and gain insights directly from experts in the field of mental health, while also enhancing your knowledge for academic success. Whether you're working on a class assignment or exploring a future career path, this panel review is the perfect platform to expand your understanding and connect with industry professionals.   

From Thursday, November 21, 2024 1:00 PM to 2:00 PM EST at Online.

item.description:
Scrappy Hour

Join your fellow Owls for a weekly tradition of enjoying a refreshing soda ice cream float (or simply have a drink and some ice cream) and mingling with Scrappy. You can take home a souvenir cup to remember the experience. So, come and join us to make some unforgettable memories with your KSU community! 

 

Scrappy Hour will happen every Thursday from 1:30-2:30 PM. The 1st and 3rd Thursday of every month will be on the Kennesaw Campus. The 2nd and 4th Thursday of every month will be on the Marietta Campus. All students, faculty, and staff are welcome!

From Thursday, November 21, 2024 1:30 PM to 2:30 PM EST at Carmichael Student Center Atrium.

item.description:
Recovery Literature Study

The Center for Young Adult Addiction and Recovery hosts weekly recovery literature studies focused on literature from recovery programs. This meeting is open to anyone wanting to know more about the texts commonly referenced in recovery programs. Each week a passage from a book will be discussed in a mutual aid space and new books will be introduced after the completion of each.

For More information, contact recovery@kennesaw.edu to learn more about the current literature study.

item.title: Fall 2024 Impact Service Group
item.description:
Fall 2024 Impact Service Group

Calling all sustainability enthusiasts!!

 

 

Be a part of making a difference through the Impact Service Group this semester! Individuals who register for the Impact Service Group will volunteer at the KSU Field Station. The mission of the Kennesaw State University Field Station is to provide a living laboratory for researchers, educators, and students, promoting an interdisciplinary learning environment conducive for experiential academic experiences and strategic collaborations within the university community and beyond. The KSU Food Forest will serve as a model of sustainable urban cultivation, and demonstrate the potential of food forest systems to mitigate climate change and promote food security and health.

 

Impact Service Group members will assist with a number of tasks including painting rock labels to identify plants, weeding, mulching, and preparing plantings.

 

Impact Service Group members will serve at the Field Station every other week from 11:00 AM to 1:00 PM beginning Tuesday, August 20th. Please complete the registration form if you are interested in joining the Impact Service Group. REGISTER HERE!!

 

Volunteers are encouraged to wear closed-toe shoes that you do not mind getting dirty. We encourage you to bring a full water bottle to stay hydrated during your time with us.

From Tuesday, August 20, 2024 12:00 PM to Tuesday, December 3, 2024 1:00 PM EST at KSU Field Station.
item.author: ksuserves@kennesaw.edu (Student Volunteerism and Service)

item.title: Year of Canada: Canadian Coffee Break
item.description:
Year of Canada: Canadian Coffee Break

Overview: Known as the “home of Canada’s favorite coffee,” try a cup of Tim Hortons while prepping for finals - - and sample a Timbits while you're there! If you dare, try Canada’s ever-popular “double double,” a cup of coffee with two creams and two sugars. The drink is so popular in Canada that in 2004 the term “double double” was added to the Canadian Oxford Dictionary. 

Year of Canada merch for attendees.

Hosted by Health Promotion and Wellness and Global Education.

This event is part of KSU's focus in 2024-25 on Canada's history, culture, geography, people, and practices. Unique "Year of Canada" merch will be available! Check out all of our events listed in OwlLife and online.

From Wednesday, December 4, 2024 10:00 AM to 4:00 PM EST at Relaxation Station in the Student Recreation and Activities Center, Suite 1200.

item.title: Wise Choices Workshop
item.description:
Wise Choices Workshop

Designed to educate students in making informed choices about drugs and alcohol, this course is taught on referral from multiple sources; including Student Conduct & Academic Integrity, Department of Fraternity & Sorority Life, Housing & Residence Life, and Department of Athletics. This three-hour workshop is taught by the Center for Young Adult Addiction and Recovery staff specializing in the field of addiction prevention and education. 


Students who participate in the Wise Choices Workshop will be charged an administrative fee for this class. Your Owl Express account will be assessed the amount of $85.00 after completion of the workshop. This fee must be paid within 30 days to avoid a Bursar's registration hold on your account. You may pay this fee on-line through Owl Express (web-check or credit card) or in person at the Bursar's Office (cash, check or money order). Please wait until you have received an email notification that the charge has been posted before you attempt to pay.

From Friday, December 6, 2024 9:00 AM to 12:00 PM EST at Kennesaw Campus CYAAR Location - University Village 6000 Building - UV 6137.
item.location: Kennesaw Campus CYAAR Location - University Village 6000 Building - UV 6137

item.title: Dining in the Nest - Marietta Campus
item.description:
Dining in the Nest - Marietta Campus
Have you wanted to make new friends but feel anxious or have a hard time finding your community? Have you been stressed out about going to the Commons or Stingers?  Then this is the event for you! We invite you to join the CPS Peer Counselors for lunch! No Meal Plan necessary. Space is LIMITED so please RSVP.
 
For the Marietta campus events, students will meet the Peer Counselors in front of Stingers between 11:45am-12:00pm.  
 
There will be a 5-minute grace period for students to arrive for this event at the meeting locations. Please arrive during this time, as the event will begin promptly. Students who arrive after will not be able to attend.
 
If you cannot attend the event after submitting your RSVP, please cancel your reservation to allow other students to participate.
Maximum 2 sign ups per student.  
 
We look forward to dining with you!

From Friday, December 6, 2024 12:00 PM to 1:00 PM EST at Marietta Campus, Stingers (meet out front at 11:45am).
item.location: Marietta Campus, Stingers (meet out front at 11:45am)

item.title: Jeffrey Gibson: They Teach Love, From the Collections of Jordan D. Schnitzer and His Family Foundation
item.description:
Jeffrey Gibson: They Teach Love, From the Collections of Jordan D. Schnitzer and His Family Foundation
Jeffrey Gibson: They Teach Love from the Collections of Jordan D. Schnitzer and His Family Foundation presents a sweeping survey of over 35 objects spanning 15 years. The exhibition includes prints, photography, painting, sculpture, installation, and video. Born in Colorado in 1972, Jeffrey Gibson is
of Cherokee heritage and a member of the Mississippi Band of Choctaw. His vibrant work is a call for Indigenous empowerment as well as queer visibility. Gibson has a Bachelor of Fine Arts from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and a Master of Fine Arts from
the Royal College of Art, London. Gibson is representing the United States at the Venice Biennale 2024—the first Indigenous artist to have a solo exhibition in the American Pavilion. This traveling exhibition is organized by the Jordan Schnitzer Museum of Art, Washington State University and is curated by Ryan Hardesty, Executive Director.
Support for this exhibition and related education and outreach programs has been made possible by a grant from the
Jordan Schnitzer Family Foundation.

From Tuesday, August 27, 2024 12:00 PM to Saturday, December 7, 2024 1:00 PM EST at Zuckerman Museum of Art.
item.author: arts@kennesaw.edu (College of the Arts)

item.title: Cherokee Printing: Then and Now
item.description:
Cherokee Printing: Then and Now
The Ruth Zuckerman Pavilion at the Zuckerman Museum of Art is pleased to feature a careful selection of archival materials and artist books from the Bentley Rare Book Museum’s Cherokee Collection. Historical works on view include a Cherokee Hymn Book, circa 1940; a New Testament of the Holy Bible translated into the Cherokee language, 1860; and a copy of Cherokee Phoenix and Indians’ Advocate, 1830; among others. Also included is a contemporary artist book by Frank Brannon from 2005 as well as several examples of his prints of the Cherokee syllabary.
The Bentley Rare Book Museum archives and primary sources exemplify history is a multitude of stories comprised of many different perspectives and viewpoints and the belief that there isn’t a single, universal story. The Museum uses primary sources and archives as tools to understand the past and its complexities.

From Tuesday, August 27, 2024 12:00 PM to Saturday, December 7, 2024 1:00 PM EST at Zuckerman Museum of Art.
item.author: arts@kennesaw.edu (College of the Arts)

item.title: Alcoholics Anonymous (AA)
item.description:
Alcoholics Anonymous (AA)

Alcoholics Anonymous is a fellowship of people who share their experience, strength and hope with each other that they may solve their common problem and help others to recover from alcoholism. 

The Courage to Change meeting of Alcoholics Anonymous is a meeting for people in recovery or seeking recovery. This group is not open to observation or academic credit.
